#topic Erlay WG Update (sr_gi, gleb)
(I dont have updates for orphan reso fwiw)

Not much to report this week. I extended the functional tests to cover all protocol violations and edge cases and started working on Warnet deployment to test Erlay. I just started running some tests on Warnet
That's all

Still looking for review on #31382 and hunting Approach ACKs on #30595

Floresta (the Rust Utreexo client) has started experimental integration of the library through its Rust wrapper: https://github.com/vinteumorg/Floresta/pull/456
They reported a significant validation speedup with the new kernel API design over the old libbitcoinconsensus API

that's cool
yes, very cool that they decided to go and experiment with already :)
hi

I opened #32317 for separating retrieving, and spending Coins from the rest of block validation. This could more easily allow for validating blocks with just the coins spent in the block without the need to maintain a full utxo set.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/32317 | kernel: Separate UTXO set access from validation functions by TheCharlatan 路 Pull Request #32317 路 bitcoin/bitcoin 路 GitHub
This is potentially useful for building things like non-assumevalid swiftsync and utreexo through a kernel API.

#topic Cluster Mempool WG Update (sdaftuar, sipa)
The next PR to review remains #31444, which has been getting some ACKs. Hopefully some more soon; it also had a review club yesterday.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31444 | cluster mempool: add txgraph diagrams/mining/eviction by sipa 路 Pull Request #31444 路 bitcoin/bitcoin 路 GitHub

On the research front, I've made two big posts on Delving, https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/how-to-linearize-your-cluster/303/68 and https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/how-to-linearize-your-cluster/303/73 with a summary of the differences between the 3 broad classes of linearization algorithms (old exponential, spanning forest based on the LP formulation from the Bitcoin Research Week, and the min-cut based
one from the 1989 paper), and benchmarks for it.
I'm planning to open a PR to implement the spanning-forest one in the next week or so.
If you want to understand the justification, and trade-offs involved, please see the posts.
That's it for me, unless there are any questions.
#topic Move the repo to bitcoin-core github organization (achow101)

This past week, the topic of moving the repo to bitcoin-core has come up again due to possible issues with conflicting moderation between bitcoin/bitcoin and bitcoin/bips. The main point is that bans are issued at the organization level, but Bitcoin Core and BIPs are really two separate projects. It is therefore conceivable that Bitcoin Core would want to ban someone, but BIPs would not, and vice versa. Under the current setup, any ban from one
repo is necessarily a ban from both because it is a ban from the organization.

The solution to this issue is to not have both Bitcoin Core and BIPs under the same organization. We already have the bitcoin-core organization where all of our new repos go anyways, it would entirely make sense to move bitcoin/bitcoin to bitcoin-core/bitcoin-core, or something like that. There's also a bitcoin-bips organization that was created a couple of years ago for this, so bips could be moved there. But I think that's for the bip editors
to discuss.
Moving the repo to bitcoin-core would also reduce administration overhead - primarily that keeping 2 organizations' member and team lists in sync is kind of annoying.

Transferring the repo is trivial - the same people are owners of both bitcoin and bitcoin-core, it's just a matter of clicking the button. However, it is also something that I think requires contributor buy-in, and notice that it's happening.

The main issue that there could be is of course that bitcoin/bitcoin is referenced in a ton of places. However, github already handles this by redirecting all links from the old repo location to the new repo location. All PRs and issues are transferred, all links automatically redirect, and git remotes will automatically redirect too so no one would even have to change their git config. All that needs to happen is that a bitcoin/bitcoin repo
cannot be created after the transfer as that will break all of the redirects.
If everyone is okay with this, I can do it right after the meeting.
sorry for the wall of text
FWIW, I have recently moved a few repos from my personal github account to the asmap org and I have not noticed any disruption, if that's a concern for anyone...
sounds good to me, as long as the old git URL will keep working , it's been the plan for as long as the bitcoin-core org exists, really
We recently moved libmultiprocess as well, from https://github.com/chaincodelabs/libmultiprocess which was moved to https://github.com/bitcoin-core/libmultiprocess
Another solution is to move the bips repo somewhere else? iirc laanwj mentioned having an org already?
There are redirects and they have worked without issue
I can attest that redirect still work for me on a project i moved 4 years ago, for what it's worth.
yes could move the bips repo as well, empty out "bitcoin" completely eventually

wouldn't moving the repo break the setup of banning from bitcoin/bitcoin, and then the person can actually comment in bitcoin-core/meta, otherwise if they both exist in the same org, how will the banne comment in meta
glozow: yes. I think moving both is preferable
(or maybe except for meta)
"libbase58" is also still in bitcoin i don't know what to do with that
Ignoring history, I think having bitcoin/bips and bitcoin-core/bitcoin makes most sense, in that BIPs are actually aiming to be a whole-Bitcoin-ecosystem wide thing.
fanquake: tbh I don't think meta is actually for banned people to appeal their ban
I'd prefer to wait a week or so with this (that is, if moving is decided) so people not present right now could say something if they want to.
What are the advantages of vacating bitcoin/bitcoin? My natural instinct would be to retain that and move bips/ out from bitcoin/?
laanwj: I think libbase58 and libblkmaker can be archived

hmm, looking at what would be left in bitcoin/, it'd just be bips/libblkmaker/libbase58. There's been discussion about moving/deprecating the latter 2 for years. So that'd just leave bips in bitcoin/.
achow101: agree
lightlike: +1
willcl-ark: It also makes organizing the organization easier. right now we have two orgs, with separate member lists. everyone is invited to both, but not everyone accepts the invites
Leaving bips in bitcoin/ and having Core in bitcoin-core/ does make sense to me, although i haven't thought about drawbacks.
if you ban someone from bitcoin-core org, aren't they unable to comment on bitcion-core/meta issues?
glozow: yes
Would the bitcoin org ownership be handed to the BIPs editors then?
Oh i see now, you're saying that's a feature not a bug
yes the parallel member list was always an annoyance to maintain
glozow: :)
achow101: I see, thanks.
sipa: I guess so? I'd still prefer to also move bips out and we can sunset bitcoin/
sipa: no i don't think so, if they want an org they can have bitcoin-bips
laanwj: +1
achow: then shouldn't oversight be changed in the moderation guidelines?
+1 laanwj, i think that makes sense
How is someone meant to open an issue if they can't open an issue
fanquake: they can also email
achow101: I don't think we want to leave bitcoin/ in a state where it could be perceived as dormant/up for grabs.
cfields: agreed
wait why are we sunsetting bitcoin/
cfields: definitely not, it would still be owned by us(?), with a readme that says go somewhere else
why wouldn't bips exist there
Slightly uncomfortable with the idea that the redirects only work if the owners of bitcoin org don't create a new bitcoin repo + giving admin up to bip editors
Why tho?
glozow: +1
achow101: wait if you have a README you don't have the redirect anymore?
fanquake: i think *our* decision here is whether to move bitcoin/bitcoin to bitcoin-core/bitcoin; the question whether bitcoin/bips moved elsewhere is up to the BIP editors
darosior: org level readme
or another repo
glozow: right, we should keep admin there to make sure it's not used for anything else
glozow: +1
sipa: then shouldn't we wait for them to have that discussion
why are we doing anything
i think it's an independent decision
not really, because we'd have to enact it for them
none of them have admin permissions
moving our repo can be done before they decide what to do with bips though
yes, that's the point
they can stay under bitcoin org, where we have ownership
or decide to move somewhere where they do
and we can maintain ownership of bitcoin/ in the meanwhile
seems odd that this is all happening because of moderation
I think the current group of owners of the bitcoin org have shown themselves to be trustworthy and i don't think we should take the risk to change it.
independently, moving bitcoin's repo to bitcoin-core makes sense, even if just for consistency and to not have to maintain parallel teams/frequent contributor lists

fanquake: yeah agree, maintaining the list is sync, as well as separating Bitcoin vs Bitcoin Core, seem more compelling reason to me.
i've had this thought for a while
moving the repo eventually was the plan for a long time already, i think any reason it was controversial disappeared into the past long ago
I'm not sure the benefit of having a single list less to sync, seems worth the risks
i think i'm in favor of moving bitcoin/bitcoin to bitcoin-core/bitcoin, and archiving libbase58/libblkmaker, if the plan is that we retain ownership of bitcoin

mostly for reasons of making real organisation structure match github repository structure

willcl-ark: i think the fact that it's not possible to ban someone from the Bitcoin Core org without also banning them from the BIPs org (whatever those orgs are) is a good motivation. It's not the reason on itself, but it demonstrates there is a mismatch in organisational structure. There is absolutely no reason why people maintaining a piece of software should have the ability to ban someone from
a standards organisation, or the other way around.
